1. Definition and Fundamentals

1.1 Definition of a Ring

A ring is a set R with two operations + and Â·, which satisfies certain axioms.

Ring Axioms in Detail

  1. Additive Group (R,+):
    • Associativity: $(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)$
    • Commutativity: $a + b = b + a$
    • Identity Element: $\exists 0 \in R: a + 0 = a$
    • Inverse Elements: $\forall a \in R \exists (-a) \in R: a + (-a) = 0$
  2. Multiplicative Semigroup (R,Â·):
    • Closure: $\forall a,b \in R: a \cdot b \in R$
    • Associativity: $\forall a,b,c \in R: (a \cdot b) \cdot c = a \cdot (b \cdot c)$
  3. Distributive Laws:
    • Left Distributivity: $\forall a,b,c \in R: a \cdot (b + c) = a \cdot b + a \cdot c$
    • Right Distributivity: $\forall a,b,c \in R: (a + b) \cdot c = a \cdot c + b \cdot c$

1.2 First Examples

Example 1: The Ring of Integers

The set $\mathbb{Z}$ with the usual addition and multiplication is a ring.

Verification of Axioms:

  • $(\mathbb{Z},+)$ is an abelian group
  • Multiplication is associative
  • The distributive laws hold

Example 2: The Ring of Residue Classes modulo n

The set $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$ with addition and multiplication modulo n is a ring.

Verification of Axioms:

  • $(\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z},+)$ is an abelian group
  • Multiplication is associative
  • The distributive laws hold

2. Important Examples and Applications

2.1 Number Rings

  • $\mathbb{Z}$: Ring of integers
  • $\mathbb{Q}$: Field of rational numbers
  • $\mathbb{R}$: Field of real numbers
  • $\mathbb{C}$: Field of complex numbers

Example: The Ring of Gaussian Integers

The set $\mathbb{Z}[i] = \{a + bi \mid a,b \in \mathbb{Z}\}$ with the usual addition and multiplication of complex numbers is a ring.

2.2 Polynomial Rings

The polynomial ring $R[X]$ over a ring R consists of all polynomials with coefficients from R.

$$P(X) = a_nX^n + a_{n-1}X^{n-1} + \cdots + a_1X + a_0$$

Example: Polynomial Ring over the Integers

The ring $\mathbb{Z}[X]$ consists of all polynomials with integer coefficients.

Examples of elements in $\mathbb{Z}[X]$:

  • $P(X) = 2X^3 - 3X + 1$
  • $Q(X) = X^2 + 5X - 2$

2.3 Matrix Rings

The ring $M_n(R)$ of $n \times n$ matrices over a ring R.

$$M_n(R) = \left\{\begin{pmatrix} a_{11} & \cdots & a_{1n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{n1} & \cdots & a_{nn} \end{pmatrix} \mid a_{ij} \in R \right\}$$

Example: Matrix Ring over the Real Numbers

The ring $M_2(\mathbb{R})$ consists of all $2 \times 2$ matrices with real entries.

Examples of elements in $M_2(\mathbb{R})$:

  • $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$
  • $B = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$

3. Special Properties and Structures

3.1 Commutative Rings

A ring is called commutative if multiplication is commutative:

$$\forall a,b \in R: a \cdot b = b \cdot a$$

Examples of commutative rings:

  • $\mathbb{Z}$, $\mathbb{Q}$, $\mathbb{R}$, $\mathbb{C}$
  • $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$
  • $R[X]$ for a commutative ring R

3.2 Rings with Unity

A ring with unity has an element 1 such that:

$$\forall a \in R: 1 \cdot a = a \cdot 1 = a$$

Examples of rings with unity:

  • $\mathbb{Z}$ with unity 1
  • $M_n(R)$ with unity $I_n$ (identity matrix)
  • $R[X]$ with unity 1

3.3 Zero Divisors and Integral Domains

An element $a \neq 0$ is called a zero divisor if there exists $b \neq 0$ with:

$$a \cdot b = 0 \text{ or } b \cdot a = 0$$

An integral domain is a commutative ring with unity without zero divisors.

Examples of integral domains:

  • $\mathbb{Z}$
  • $\mathbb{Q}$, $\mathbb{R}$, $\mathbb{C}$
  • $R[X]$ for an integral domain R

4. Substructures and Ideals

4.1 Subrings

A subset S âŠ† R is a subring if:

  1. S is an additive subgroup of R
  2. $\forall a,b \in S: a \cdot b \in S$

Examples of subrings:

  • $\mathbb{Z}$ is a subring of $\mathbb{Q}$
  • $\mathbb{Q}$ is a subring of $\mathbb{R}$
  • $\mathbb{R}$ is a subring of $\mathbb{C}$

4.2 Ideals

A subset I âŠ† R is an ideal if:

  1. I is an additive subgroup of R
  2. $\forall a \in I, r \in R: r \cdot a \in I$ and $a \cdot r \in I$

Examples of ideals:

  • $n\mathbb{Z}$ is an ideal in $\mathbb{Z}$
  • $(X)$ is an ideal in $R[X]$
  • $\{0\}$ and R are always ideals in R

5. Ring Homomorphisms and Quotient Rings

5.1 Ring Homomorphisms

A mapping $f: R \to S$ between rings is called a homomorphism if:

  1. $\forall a,b \in R: f(a + b) = f(a) + f(b)$
  2. $\forall a,b \in R: f(a \cdot b) = f(a) \cdot f(b)$

Examples of ring homomorphisms:

  • $f: \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}, a \mapsto [a]$
  • $f: R[X] \to R, P(X) \mapsto P(0)$
  • $f: M_n(R) \to R, A \mapsto \det(A)$

5.2 Quotient Rings and the Homomorphism Theorem

For a ring homomorphism f, the homomorphism theorem states:

$$R/\ker(f) \cong \text{im}(f)$$

Examples of quotient rings:

  • $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z} \cong \mathbb{Z}/\ker(f)$
  • $R[X]/(X) \cong R$
  • $M_n(R)/\{A \mid \det(A) = 0\} \cong R^*$

6. Applications and Advanced Topics

6.1 Number Theory

  • Residue class rings $\mathbb{Z}/n\mathbb{Z}$
  • Gaussian integers $\mathbb{Z}[i]$
  • Algebraic numbers

Examples from number theory:

  • Prime numbers in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$
  • Quadratic number fields
  • Eisenstein integers

6.2 Algebraic Geometry

  • Polynomial rings and varieties
  • Local rings
  • Valuation rings

Examples from algebraic geometry:

  • Coordinate rings of curves
  • Local rings of singularities
  • Valuation rings of function fields
